text: I held Lucia back and whispered, “Don’t move. We’ll circle from the side.” The firelight flickered along the walls, and shadows danced like torn cloth.
The ground was damp, snow tracked in from outside melting into thin trails of water. I crept along the wall, breathing so lightly it was almost soundless.
🎲 [Agility Check: Success] You silently slip behind a stone pillar. The blue glow of the formation flickers faintly across your face.
Lucia crouched on the other side, lips moving soundlessly to form two words—“the mentor.”
I followed her gaze. Alicia was bound at the center of the ritual circle, her hair in disarray, the light of her amulet nearly extinguished. Her chest rose and fell slightly—she was still alive.
The robed figures chanted in low unison, their rhythm pulsing like a heartbeat. At the center, the leader lifted his hand, blue light flowing between his palms.
“I’ll draw their attention—you go and break the chains,” I murmured quietly.
Lucia hesitated for a moment, then nodded firmly.
I glanced around. On the left, a cracked iron pipe ran up toward the ceiling—maybe it could make some noise. Taking a deep breath, I picked up a stone.
The stone flew and struck the pipe with a sharp clang—“TANG!”
“Who’s there?”
The cultists turned their heads. The leader’s voice was sharp and commanding.
Two of them broke away to investigate. Taking advantage of the distraction, I crawled to the next pillar while Lucia crept closer to Alicia.
She whispered an incantation; light spread along the chains with a faint hiss.
I held my breath as the leader raised his hand again, sensing the disturbance in the flow of energy.
“No more waiting.”
I sprang from the shadows, my short sword flashing cold in the dim light, driving straight into the nearest cultist’s side.
He grunted and collapsed, blood splattering across the glowing runes. The light flickered violently, and the chanting faltered into chaos.
Lucia seized the chance and broke the final chain. Alicia fell into her arms, unconscious.
“Foolish mortals,” the leader roared, “you have disrupted the purification ritual!”
He pressed his hands together, the runes beneath his feet flaring once more. I lunged forward, kicking his staff aside. The blue light wavered, and the formation exploded in a violent flash.
The shockwave tore through the air, deafening in its force. I was nearly thrown off my feet.
When I opened my eyes again, the leader lay motionless on the floor, the mark on his chest slowly fading. The remaining cultists fled, leaving the chamber in eerie silence.
The air reeked of smoke and ash. The blue glow faded away, leaving only faint sparks flickering in the dark.
“She’s breathing—but barely.”
“Come on, let’s get out of here.”
I tightened my grip on the sword and led the way. The stairs were slick, water dripping from the walls.
Cold wind hit us in the face. Snow was still falling, and the streetlights shone dimly through the storm like a yellow mist.
“That was… too close.”
She panted, eyes wide with disbelief and a spark of exhilaration.
“Close—but worth it.”
I looked down at Alicia in my arms. “She’s alive.”
We turned to look back at the ruined building—the blue glow was gone. The wind stirred the snow, erasing our tracks.
“…Thank you…”
Her voice murmured faintly in her sleep.
The words were nearly lost to the wind, yet they made my chest tighten. It sounded less like gratitude—and more like a warning, or a memory.
“What did she say?”
“She’s alive. That’s all that matters.”
I sighed and draped my cloak over Alicia’s shoulders. In the distance, the town bell tolled—midnight.
Wind coiled around the street corners, lanterns swaying softly. In that moment, I realized—we hadn’t just saved a life, but unearthed a buried truth.
